newsitem.title: UK: Britain's House of Lords backs EU withdrawal bill.
newsitem.headline: Britain's House of Lords backs EU withdrawal bill.

text.p: The anti-Brussels wing of Britain's ruling Conservative Party scored a minor triumph on Friday when the upper House of Lords backed a bill which would effectively mean Britain's withdrawal from the European Union.

The bill, proposed by Conservative Lord John Pearson, has no chance of becoming law despite approval after an initial debate by 52 votes to 51 in the unelected house -- and apparent backing from former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.
It would repeal legislation passed when Britain joined the EU in 1972 under which EU law was made superior to British legislation.
Thatcher sat through the first half of a 6-1/2 hour debate on the bill, occasionally nodding at points made by its supporters, but left before the vote.
But former cabinet minister Lord Norman Tebbit, one of her most loyal political supporters, spoke for the bill.
He said it could provide a means by which Britons who opposed the further ceding of sovereignty to Brussels could confront advocates in other EU states of a federal Europe.
"The Bill before us, if enacted, would create the crisis in Europe which is needed for the discussions to begin to make a serious effort to solve these problems," Tebbit said.

Government minister Lord Richard Inglewood said the bill would leave Britain in breach of its obligations under EU treaties. "In such circumstances we would not have any choice but to withdraw," he said.
"This Bill is quite simply against Government policy and Britain's interests," he added.

The bill would have to go through further stages in the Lords and then be passed by the lower House of Commons before it could become law -- something that is inconceivable with an election expected within the next three months.

Prime Minister John Major has been battling for years to control the so-called Eurosceptic wing of his party, refusing their attempts to make him rule out British participation in new EU developments such as the planned single currency.

But earlier this week, party chairman Brian Mawhinney effectively gave permission to more than 100 Conservative candidates in the forthcoming election to declare their opposition to a single currency in their personal manifestos.
